item.title: December 22‚Äì26, 2025
item.description:
THREE BIG THINGS THIS WEEK

  1. As the year winds down and everyone enjoys their holiday season the development pace of FIMS will be slightly slower over this week and the following week. Please take time to enjoy your friends and family.

  2. We are working on a hot-fix release to 0.7.0 that fixes a few üêõüêõ. At the last Code Club we prioritized closing all üêõ issues and this will stay a priority until it is finished.

  3. Bai is working on a Pull Request to establish a bash script to set up FIMS, which will be helpful for Google Cloud workstations. It has also been helpful to test out the install process on several different types of machines. Feel free to give feedback here on FIMS Discussion 1073.

HELPFUL RESOURCES

  • FIMS Outreach Activities
  • NMFS Open Science Calendar
  • Implementation Team Notes
  • FIMS FAQs
  • NOAA-FIMS Discussions
  • GitHub Trainings

FIMS ANNOUNCEMENTS

UPCOMING EVENTS

PHOTO OF THE WEEK

x %notin% table is currently in the development version of R and is an idiom for !(x %in% table) and provided almost entirely for convenience and code readability, from an R-devel suggestion, after many years of private definitions mostly hidden in packages, including in R‚Äôs {tools}.

x <- 1
my_vector <- 1:10
x %notin% my_vector

item.title: December 15‚Äì19, 2025
item.description:
THREE BIG THINGS THIS WEEK

  1. Thanks to Meg for reporting a :bug: last week, we will have a new release of 0.7.0 hopefully today, i.e., 0.7.1 that fixes the json and the R code to read that json in.

  2. Matthew has picked back up the length-based selectivity work and is hoping to get this wrapped up soon and in a new release.

  3. The projections branch will be rebased to dev and a vignette will be created to help socialize how to do projections. If you are interested in helping with this please reach out on the Pull Request.

  • NOAA-FIMS Discussions

UPCOMING EVENTS

Wednesday,

FIMS Code Club Time: 13:00‚Äì16:00 E; 10:00‚Äì13:00 P; 9:00‚Äì12:00 AK; 7:00‚Äì10:00 H Location: Virtual Online: Google Meet

PHOTO OF THE WEEK

Has anyone heard of {fastverse} before? It appears to be a {tidyverse} style group of packages built on C++ code that is meant for quick analyses of data, unlike traditional tidyverse packages that are known to be easy to understand but slow. See the code below for installation and feel free to start a Discussion on GitHub about the packages if they seem useful, especially as our input and output data frames become larger.

item.title: December 08‚Äì12, 2025
item.description:
THREE BIG THINGS THIS WEEK

  1. v0.7.0 will be released this week, thanks to Matthew for finishing up the model families code and Bai and Adrianne for working on cleanup tasks while the rest of us were away from our desks.

  2. The code for projections just needs a vignette, which will be worked on this week, then we can release this PR next week hopefully.

  3. Implementation of ‚Äòepics‚Äô in the issue tracker will start this week in an effort to help communicate the timeline. Epics are essentially parent issues that help link small issues to a larger feature.

HELPFUL RESOURCES

  • FIMS Outreach Activities
  • NMFS Open Science Calendar
  • Implementation Team Notes
  • FIMS FAQs
  • NOAA-FIMS Discussions
  • GitHub Trainings

FIMS ANNOUNCEMENTS

  • Consider attending the CAPAM workshop on tuna models this week.

UPCOMING EVENTS

PHOTO OF THE WEEK

A new expectation expect_shape() is available from {testthat} which checks the dimensions of the object of interest, e.g., number of rows or number of columns! This function could be helpful for FIMS where we expect the model results to have a certain number of rows.

testthat::expect_shape()

args(testthat::expect_shape)
# function (object, ..., nrow, ncol, dim)

mat <- matrix(1:6, nrow = 2, ncol = 3)
# Passes: mat has 2 rows and 3 columns
testthat::expect_shape(mat, c(2, 3))

df <- data.frame(a = 1:4, b = 5:8)
# Passes: df has 4 rows and 2 columns
testthat::expect_shape(df, c(4, 2))

item.title: December 01‚Äì05, 2025
item.description:
THREE BIG THINGS THIS WEEK

  1. Our number one goal this week is to get a new release out, which involves trudging through the 13 open Pull Requests and prioritizing which ones will be a part of 0.8.0 and need rebased and which ones will wait for the next release.

  2. Bai is working hard on sorting out the differences between FIMS and other software in an effort to ramp up the testing in FIMS.

  3. Effort on the Surplus Production Model is ramping back up. Again, testing has revealed differences between FIMS and other frameworks that needs to be sorted out.

item.title: November 24‚Äì28, 2025
item.description:
THREE BIG THINGS THIS WEEK

  1. This week‚Äôs Code Club will be our first installment of a 3-hour time window for coding. You can think of this as a monthly hackathon now instead of our weekly sessions. We will work on (1) reviewing the outstanding Pull Requests to dev, (2) writing a log statement for the newest version that is about to be released, and (3) updating the cheat sheet given the changes to the R interface. Breakout rooms will allow you to work on things in a quiet space or in small groups if desired.

  2. With the shortened week because of the holiday, I am not certain we will be able to get a release out but we will at least work towards that goal.

  3. Now that the ICES Methods Group Working Group is over, we will resume forward progress on the Surplus Production Model, which will be our second release from now.

  • Happy ü¶ÉThanksgiving Dayü¶É to you and your friends and family this holiday season.
  • The FIMS CIE Review has been rescheduled to April 21‚Äì23, 2026.

UPCOMING EVENTS

Tuesday,

FIMS Code Club Time: 13:00‚Äì16:00 E; 10:00‚Äì13:00 P; 9:00‚Äì12:00 AK; 7:00‚Äì10:00 H Location: Virtual Online: Google Meet

PHOTO OF THE WEEK

A few months ago, Posit introduced Databot to help explore your data. This is not really of direct interest to FIMS but I think the concept is. Our figures and tables should with a FIMS data object should be relatively similar where we build a command such as summarize() to give similar summaries.

item.title: November 17‚Äì21, 2025
item.description:
THREE BIG THINGS THIS WEEK

  1. Welcome back all! Last week was spent catching up on emails and getting reorientated, where this week we will be working towards getting a release out within the next two weeks. Thank you to Bai, Adrianne, and Nathan for keeping the lights on.

  2. We will no longer be having our Seaside Chats on Thursdays. Instead, we will be scheduling calls that work with people‚Äôs schedules based on need. We encourage everyone to schedule these types of calls within the FIMS community based on your own needs. Just remember to add them to the FIMS calendar.

  3. The CIE Review will be rescheduled for next Spring. Before the review we will ensure that all work done in preparation for the review is solid and that the documentation has been vetted with new users to ensure that it is understandable to non-developers.

item.description:
THREE BIG THINGS THIS WEEK

  1. A new release of FIMS will come out this week that contains the PRs brought in last week thanks to Bai and Eric as well as improvements to the documentation thanks to those that showed up to Code Club and the extra design document meetings. Everyone‚Äôs work is greatly appreciated. Check out the issues listed in the CIE cleanup milestone for more tasks to work on.

  2. Once a bug in the likelihood calculations is fixed in dev-json-caa, this branch will be merged into dev. By the end of the day today though it will be rebased and Nathan can branch off it to start adding projections and Meg and Ian can use it for their diagnostic work.

  3. The case studies are mid-stream in an update to use {asar} and {stockplotr} for plotting. Thanks to help from Kyle and Sam we have two case studies nearly complete and we hope to get some help porting over the remaining ones this week.

PHOTO OF THE WEEK

doxygen use to be so foreign to me and I wished we could just use roxygenüòí. Now, I feel more at home with doxygen and have even learned some tips (see below) to making it better and feel more roxygen like‚úÖ.

// To make a table of contents in a .md file
[TOC]

// Copy documentation from another function
@copydoc MyFunctionName

// Link to a function or file
`FunctionName()` `my_file.hpp`

// Insert an inline or block equation
\f$a-b=c/f$
\f[ \text{best} = \alpha - \beta \f]

Thanks to Bai‚Äôs recent PR that revamped the lists of lists for running a model into a tibble the amount of code needed to run a default model is even less. Check out the revamped fims-demo-minimal below!

data_4_model <- FIMSFrame(data1)
# Create parameters
parameters <- data_4_model |>
  create_default_configurations() |>
  create_default_parameters(data = data_4_model)
# Run the  model with optimization
fit <- parameters |>
  initialize_fims(data = data_4_model) |>
  fit_fims(optimize = TRUE)

UPCOMING EVENTS

Tuesday, json in R

FIMS Code Club Time: 13:00‚Äì16:00 E; 10:00‚Äì13:00 P; 9:00‚Äì12:00 AK; 7:00‚Äì10:00 H Location: Virtual Online: Google Meet

Thursday, data and seasonality

FIMS Seaside Chat Time: 13:00‚Äì14:00 E; 10:00‚Äì11:00 P; 9:00‚Äì10:00 AK; 7:00‚Äì8:00 H Location: Virtual Online: Google Meet

PHOTO OF THE WEEK

Last week I showed the json output for dimensionality, this week I show the tidyverse code to create a tibble from that same information.

#' Covert the dimension information from a FIMS json output into a tibble
#'
#' Dimensions in the json output are stored as a list of length two, with the
#' header information containing the name of the dimension and the dimensions
#' containing integers specifying the length for each dimension. The result
#' helps interpret how the FIMS output is structured given it is dimension
#' folded into a single vector in the json output.
#'
#' @param data A list containing the header and dimensions information from a
#'   FIMS json output object.
#' @return
#' A tibble containing ordered rows for each combination of the dimensions.
#' @examples
#' dummy_dimensions <- list(
#'   header = list("nyears", "nages"),
#'   dimensions = list(30L, 12L)
#' )
#' dimensions_to_tibble(dummy_dimensions)
dimensions_to_tibble <- function(data) {
  # Create names that are informative for columns b/c nyears is not helpful
  better_names <- unlist(data[["header"]]) |>
    gsub(pattern = "^n(.+)s$", replacement = "\\1_ids")
  names(data[["dimensions"]]) <- better_names
  # Create the returned tibble by first sequencing from 1:n for each dimension
  data[["dimensions"]] |>
    purrr::map(seq) |>
    expand.grid() |>
    tibble::as_tibble() |>
    dplyr::arrange(!!! rlang::syms(better_names))
}

item.title: September 01‚Äì05, 2025
item.description:
THREE BIG THINGS THIS WEEK

  1. We are working on three pull requests right now, revamped model-specification interface, revamped json output, and addition of the surplus production model. The goal is to get at least two of the three merged this week and get dev cleaned up so it is passing tests.

  2. Kyle and Kelli are working on using {asar} and {stockplotr} for the case studies to increase consistency.

item.title: August 25‚Äì29, 2025
item.description:
THREE BIG THINGS THIS WEEK

  1. Bai is busy revamping the way users interact with the model parameters as lists of lists has gotten unwieldy.

  2. Matthew and Andrea are working on different parts of the model using feature branches off of the latest dev branch that has a draft of the Surplus Production Model (SPM).

I recently learned about Deep Wiki where you can view a Wiki about any repository that is available on GitHub. I looked to see what Deep Wiki had to say about FIMS and first found it was not indexed but all it took to change that was proving my email. Within minutes, FIMS had its own page. Several diagrams were generated but the one that I thought was the most helpful (see below) summarized what is available in the main branch for the C++ code. I think this image will be extremely helpful as FIMS becomes more complex. I just wish I knew how we can create it dynamically ‚òπÔ∏è

item.title: August 11‚Äì15, 2025
item.description:
THREE BIG THINGS THIS WEEK

  1. Sorry for the late FIMS Weekly but I have been sick ü§ï and just haven‚Äôt been able to muster enough üî•to get one together. I am doing better today but still don‚Äôt have much of a voice so there is no seaside chat this week.

  2. v0.6.3 will be released this week, thanks to Andrea finding an intermittent bug when using TMBad on Windows regarding how we were implementing operators in fims_math.hpp.

  3. Lots of work is co-occurring in several branches, I will be missing some in the following list but I hope this helps people get a pulse üíì on what is going on: (a) Matthew - dev-length-selectivity-rebased trying to find üêõ in length likelihood, (b) Alex - dev-dbl-norm implementing double normal selectivity, (c) Andrea - dev-osa adding one-step-ahead residuals, (d) Nathan & Andrea - dev-projections-[nathan|andrea] projections, (e) Bai - dev-refactor-nested-parameter-list updating R side of model input, and (f) Kathryn - in ghactions4r allowing /document to work.

FIMS ANNOUNCEMENTS

  • This will be the last FIMS Weekly in Google Doc form because Elizabeth created a way to distribute this via html on our FIMS Website üéâ. Emails will still go out but they will just link to where you can find the weekly and maybe a screen shot. I am not sure. Please feel free to email me suggestions.
  • The collaborative workflow repository will be removed once the material is migrated to our beautiful FIMS website. Stay tuned.

UPCOMING EVENTS

Tuesday, August 12

FIMS Code Club (WSL and docker) Time: 13:00‚Äì16:00 E; 10:00‚Äì13:00 P; 9:00‚Äì12:00 AK; 7:00‚Äì10:00 H Location: Virtual Online: Google Meet

PHOTO OF THE WEEK

During our GitHub training with Microsoft, Bai asked a ‚ùìabout git worktrees that kind of blew my mind. I had yet to understand the full question or the response but last week with the new version of VS Code that was released it started to make sense. VS Code now has support for git worktrees, where worktrees let you check out multiple branches at once within a single clone. This stops the need for having multiple clones of the same repository on a single computer. IMO this is genius. I am constantly making bogus commits or stashing things that I later forgot that I stashed so I can check out a different branch, do one thing, and then switch back to the other branch. Or worse yet, I am on a branch and want to see a file in a different branch so I go online copy and paste the raw text from the ‚Äúother‚Äù branch that I am interested in and then put it in a new file in VS Code. All of these alternates are suboptimal and have led to üß®, which is obviously not good. I am excited to check out the use of worktrees and if it goes well maybe we can get Jonathan to do a GitHub training on them. First, I had to click on the three dots to the right of ‚ÄúSOURCE CONTROL‚Äù and add ‚ÄúRepositories‚Äù to what was being shown in my ‚ÄúSOURCE CONTROL‚Äù section of VS Code. Second, I clicked the three dots to the left of REPOSITORIES/FIMS, where I currently have dev-fix-exp-TMBad checked out, which brought up a list where I selected Worktrees -> Create Worktree and let me select an additional branch. I chose dev. Now you can see dev is a worktree in the list under FIMS. This is as far as I have gotten in my üõ£Ô∏è.

item.title: August 04‚Äì08, 2025
item.description:
THREE BIG THINGS THIS WEEK

  1. The case studies will be updated this week to use the latest release. This has been done in dev for a while but just hanging in the ether.

  2. We will be migrating several resources from individual repositories to the FIMS website, e.g., FIMS Weekly newsletter, training repo, doxygen documentation, and potentially the collaborative workflow.

  3. Please ensure that your affiliation in the FIMS manuscript is correct, which will be submitted to ICES Journal of Marine Science at the beginning of next week.

HELPFUL RESOURCES

  • FIMS Outreach Activities
  • NMFS Open Science Calendar
  • Implementation Team Notes
  • FIMS FAQs
  • NOAA-FIMS Discussions
  • GitHub Trainings

FIMS ANNOUNCEMENTS

  • FIMS website is now newly updated thanks to Elizabeth ü•á!
  • The CIE Review has been approved and will be held November 04‚Äì06, 2025 using an online platform.

UPCOMING EVENTS

Tuesday, August 05

FIMS Code Club (json) Time: 13:00‚Äì16:00 E; 10:00‚Äì13:00 P; 9:00‚Äì12:00 AK; 7:00‚Äì10:00 H Location: Virtual Online: Google Meet

Wednesday, August 06

FIMS Implementation Team Meeting (Projections)

Time: 15:30‚Äì16:30 E; 12:30‚Äì13:30 P; 11:30‚Äì12:30 AK; 9:30‚Äì10:30 H Location: Virtual Online: Google meet

PHOTO OF THE WEEK

During last week‚Äôs Seaside Chat, it was proposed that we should make a json schema for the FIMS output and I agree üíØ. Gemini then told me that referencing schemas is a thing, which led me down a ‚Äúbright‚Äù üê∞üï≥Ô∏è. I realized that the .bib files for LaTeX that I normally work with are essentially a json file. Gemini also informed me that BioSchemas is the most referenced schema in science, particularly their Dataset schema. Below is an example:

{
  "@context": "https://schema.org/",
  "@type": "Dataset",
  "name": "Human Genome Assembly GRCh38",
  "description": "The latest full reference genome assembly of the human genome, a product of the Genome Reference Consortium.",
  "url": "https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/assembly/GCF_000001405.26/",
  "identifier": "GCF_000001405.26",
  "creator": {
    "@type": "Organization",
    "name": "Genome Reference Consortium"
  },
  "citation": "Kallberg, M. et al. (2014). GRCh38: The human reference genome update. Nucleic Acids Research.",
  "keywords": [
    "Human Genome",
    "GRCh38",
    "Genomics",
    "Reference Assembly"
  ],
  "license": "https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/",
  "datePublished": "2013-12-17",
  "distribution": [
    {
      "@type": "DataDownload",
      "name": "GRCh38 FASTA file",
      "contentUrl": "ftp://ftp.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genomes/all/GCF/000/001/405/GCF_000001405.26_GRCh38/GCF_000001405.26_GRCh38_genomic.fna.gz",
      "encodingFormat": "application/x-fasta"
    }
  ],
  "measurementTechnique": "Next-Generation Sequencing",
  "inLanguage": "en"
}

item.title: July 28‚ÄìAugust 1, 2025
item.description:
THREE BIG THINGS THIS WEEK

  1. Writing tests üß™ for length-based selectivity and finding the remaining üêõ.

  2. Meg and Ian are working on FIMSdiags. If you are interested in joining them, watch the FIMS Calendar for meetings or ask Meg specifically to be invited.

  3. Projections and reference points are in the works. An update will be presented at the next FIMS Implementation Team Meeting.

HELPFUL RESOURCES

  • FIMS Outreach Activities
  • NMFS Open Science Calendar
  • Implementation Team Notes
  • FIMS FAQs
  • NOAA-FIMS Discussions
  • GitHub Trainings

FIMS ANNOUNCEMENTS

  • Version 0.6.2 is the newest version of FIMS thanks to Andrea fixing a üêõ that was found while initiating the Windows make file to use TMBad.
  • We need a volunteer to lead Seaside Chat on Thursday if we would like to keep it because Kelli will be on Annual Leave Wednesday‚ÄìFriday.

UPCOMING EVENTS

PHOTO OF THE WEEK

Elizabeth Perl has been working on revamping the NOAA-FIMS github.io site and has been making fantastic progress. The new website should be live in about a week or so. Thank you to Meg for your initial work on revamping the website that showed something like this was possible, Alex for suggesting that we needed to condense our resources instead of having them scattered about, and Elizabeth for taking on this massive task.

item.title: July 21‚Äì25, 2025
item.description:
THREE BIG THINGS THIS WEEK

  1. We are now successfully building FIMS on ALL operating systems on GitHub actions and R-universe thanks to many hours from Andrea, Bai, and Matthew. Way to go üí™üëç! This week we will continue to work on problems with {devtools} ü§¶ to see if we should submit an issue to {devtools} or if we just will not be able to run devtools::test() multiple times in a row.
  2. Initial testing and design of projections and reference points has started and will continue this week. Projections and reference points will more than likely be the topic of interest for our next Implementation Team Meeting. So, get ready to make some decisions.
  3. Length-based selectivity is coming along and will be rebased to the current dev branch this week.

HELPFUL RESOURCES

  • FIMS Outreach Activities
  • NMFS Open Science Calendar
  • Implementation Team Notes
  • FIMS FAQs
  • NOAA-FIMS Discussions

FIMS ANNOUNCEMENTS

UPCOMING EVENTS

Tuesday, July 22

FIMS Code Club (Tackling TODO: items in code)
Time: 13:00‚Äì14:00 E; 10:00‚Äì11:00 P; 9:00‚Äì10:00 AK; 7:00‚Äì8:00 H
Location: Virtual
Online: Google Meet

Thursday, July 24

FIMS Seaside Chat (ü§∑)
Time: 13:00‚Äì14:00 E; 10:00‚Äì11:00 P; 9:00‚Äì10:00 AK; 7:00‚Äì8:00 H
Location: Virtual
Online: Google Meet

PHOTO OF THE WEEK

R-opensci has guidance on writing tests for packages submitted that Bai is looking into. But, it was pretty mind blowing to learn that there is a way to add comments to a commit message that can invoke ‚Äúextended‚Äù tests, i.e., tests that do not need to be run on every commit. It was nice to know that others have been thinking about this as FIMS has struggled to find a resource or advice on what to do, see Discussion #870. Feel free to add any thoughts about the system below or other insights to running large tests on the Discussion board. Thank you in advance for taking the time to contribute üòä.
